article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Exploring Cognitive Readiness in Complex Operational Environments: Advances in Theory and Practice, Part II

abstract.p: The previous special issue featured articles on the theme of presenting the latest advances in cognitive readiness research in terms of both theory development and practical applications across domains. For researchers, this translates into addressing important research gaps and identifying areas warranting further investigation. For practitioners, this translates into useful and practical recommendations and lessons learned for promoting cognitive readiness in complex domains. The editors continue this theme in this special issue with two more articles that address this important topic. It is their hope that the findings and lessons learned presented in this three-part special issue will provide a basis for future research aimed at creating more cognitively ready individuals and teams.

body.p: Cognitive readiness can be described as the state of possessing the psychological (mental) and sociological (social) knowledge, skills and abilities, and attitudes needed to sustain consistent, competent professional performance and mental well-being in dynamic, complex, and unpredictable environments (Bolstad, Cuevas, Babbitt, Semple, & Vestewig, 2006; Morrison & Fletcher, 2002). The previous special issue of this volume featured the latest advances in cognitive readiness research in terms of both theory development and practical applications across domains. For researchers, this translates into addressing important research gaps and identifying areas warranting further investigation. For practitioners, this translates into useful and practical recommendations and lessons learned for promoting cognitive readiness in complex domains.

Part 1 of the special issue began with an introduction by the editors, followed by three articles that examined a variety of topics, including identifying the general challenges associated with the institutionalization of cognitive readiness (Fautua & Schatz, 2012); designing decision support systems with consideration for three factors that influence cognitive readiness, namely, adaptability, flexibility, and acceptability (Cegarra & van Wezel, 2012); and presenting a theoretical framework to guide the development of training for team cognitive readiness in small units (Fiore, Ross, & Jentsch, 2012). We continue this theme in Part 2 of the special issue with two more articles exploring cognitive readiness: a theoretical model for measuring military cognitive readiness at the operational and strategic levels (Grier, 2012) and an empirical evaluation of two decision support tools, focused on three components of individual cognitive readiness in complex operations, namely, situation awareness, problem solving, and decision making (Lafond, DuCharme, Gagnon, & Tremblay, 2012).

A forthcoming issue will present Part 3 of the special issue. This will begin with a preface by Patrick Mason, Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, which discusses the importance of cognitive readiness for human performance and operational effectiveness and identifies several challenges that must be addressed in future research (Mason & McQuade). The specific issues that will be addressed by the three articles in Part 3 include evaluating a team psychophysiological approach to measuring cognitive readiness during a complex and dynamic task (Walker, Muth, Switzer, & Rosopa), using eye-based psychophysiological cues to enhance screener vigilance (Langhals, Burgoon, & Nunamaker), and guidelines on how to conduct training of cognitive readiness research emphasizing transfer of cognitive readiness components to dynamic, stressful unpredictable environments (Kluge & Burkolter). As in Part 1, the articles selected for Parts 2 and 3 cover a diverse range of issues and approaches from researchers in academia, industry, and government organizations, including both national and international representation.

From a theoretical perspective, collectively, the research findings reported in this three-part special issue significantly contribute to our understanding of the broad range of cognitive, behavioral, and attitudinal factors that influence cognitive readiness in complex operational environments. From a practical perspective, each article concludes with useful recommendations and/or implications for theory or practice. It is our hope that the findings and lessons learned presented in this three-part special issue will provide a basis for future research aimed at creating more cognitively ready individuals and teams.

Their valuable feedback and commentary helped the authors improve the clarity of their manuscripts and enhance the scientific and practical contributions of their research. bio.p: Dylan D. Schmorrow is an acquisition professional in the Naval Acquisition Corps serving in the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Research and Engineering) as the deputy director for human performance, training and biosystems with purview over the defense technology areas of human performance, medical, man–machine systems, training, civil engineering, environmental quality, and chemical and biological defense. He holds a PhD in experimental psychology from Western Michigan University.

Cheryl A. Bolstad is a principal research associate at SA Technologies. She completed her PhD in psychology at North Carolina State University, specializing in cognition and aging. She has 20 years of experience as a human factors engineer investigating numerous research areas, including design, training, and assessment of situation awareness in individuals and teams; team performance analysis and measurement; training program development and evaluation; cognitive readiness assessment; and collaborative tool design.

Katrina A. May is an engineering psychologist for the Army Research Laboratory Human Research and Engineering Directorate. As part of the Combat Cognition and Readiness Team, she has investigated net workload, team workload, networked science, cognition, and cognitive readiness. She is chair emeritus of the Department of Defense Human Factors Engineering Technical Advisory Group (TAG), where she founded currently cochairs the Cognitive Readiness subTAG. She received a master’s degree in psychology from Towson University.

Haydee M. Cuevas is an assistant professor at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (ERAU). Prior to joining ERAU, she worked as a research associate III at SA Technologies, Inc. for more than 7 years. She has more than 15 years of experience as a human factors researcher working on numerous Department of Defense-, government-, and industry-funded projects investigating a broad range of human performance issues in complex operational environments. She has a PhD in applied experimental and human factors psychology from the University of Central Florida.
